awd_titl_txt: Access to Innovative Education: STEM Opportunities for Students with Learning Disabilities (AIE-STEM)
awd_abstract_narration:
Students with learning disabilities (LD) (particularly those with autism spectrum disorder) are not being hired as workers in STEM fields at rates that match their peers. There is a critical need to recruit, educate, and mentor students with LD to join the STEM workforce beyond graduation, especially as many of these bright individuals hold compensatory gifts that make them well-suited for particular areas within STEM fields. The Access to Innovative Education: STEM Opportunities for Students with Learning Disabilities (AIE-STEM) project will provide scholarship support for students at Landmark College studying Computer Science or Life Sciences. As Landmark College exclusively serves LD students, including attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD), all AIE-STEM scholars will have a diagnosed LD. The AIE-STEM project will provide between 5 and 13 scholarships annually to low-income, academically promising students with LD (24 unique students will be served by the AIE-STEM program over five years). In addition to financial support, the AIE-STEM project will provide students with mentoring, internship opportunities, research experiences, and peer support. Mentoring will be provided by Landmark College faculty in the discipline. Research will focus on the impact of mentoring on the LD identity development and positive experiences in internship and research placements.

The research component of the project will investigate how effective mentoring leads to better outcomes for students with LD in STEM fields. In particular, it is hypothesized that a stronger LD identity is formed via mentoring and leads to positive experiences in internship and research placements. Two specific research questions will be addressed through the AIE-STEM project: (1) In what ways does mentoring assist students in developing a healthy Disabilities Identity, and (2) In what ways does mentoring impact success in internship experiences and research?  All AIE-STEM students will take a measure of Learning Disabilities Identity Development (LDID) to provide baseline data. Throughout the first year, students will participate in monthly cohort meetings and begin meeting with a faculty mentor. In Year 2, students will identify undergraduate research projects and/or internship placements. During the final meeting of each award year, participants will again complete the LDID measure and measures of mentorship involvement. At this final cohort meeting, a focus group interview will be conducted to collect information about mentoring effectiveness. Disabilities Identity Development data will be analyzed to assess the effectiveness of mentoring in the psychosocial aspect. Data collected from the mentoring measures will inform the impact of mentoring on research and internship experiences. Data collected about mentoring effectiveness will be used to make ongoing corrections to the mentor model. The data will also inform best practice related to mentoring students with LD.

por.por_cntn:
Neurodiverse students are underrepresented in STEM fields yet hold tremendous potential for contributing significantly to these areas. Understanding the supports needed for low-income, academically talented neurodiverse students to thrive in STEM disciplines is a key first-step to unlocking a currently underutilized resource. Key indicators were increased graduation and retention rates, and engagement in internship and research activities.

The purpose of AIE-STEM is to support STEM engagement and retention among college students who have learning differences. The potential benefit of diversity in STEM is widely accepted, yet this population of students, who think and learn differently, is less likely to earn a degree than their peers. AIE-STEM has been a multi-year program aiding 40 unique students through financial aid and a program of support to increase their commitment to the field. Participating students, known as “STEM scholars,” provided annual input, which we have used to assess and improve the program.  

Who are the STEM scholars? Financially qualifying, full-time students pursuing an associate or baccalaureate degree in Life Science or Computer Science at Landmark College are eligible for AIE-STEM. Landmark College focuses exclusively on serving students who have a learning difference, including learning disabilities such as dyslexia, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and/or autism, collectively referred to as neurodiverse (referred to herein as ND) students. Neurodivergent and neurodiversity are used as terms of empowerment rather than a diagnosis or disorder.

Scholars cited that faculty-mentoring and structured cohort-building activities are most impactful to them on their STEM journey. The aim of faculty mentoring is to teach students how to engage in a specific (STEM) community while also developing a sense of self as a STEM student and practitioner. Therefore, mentoring has focused on the acquisition of STEM-related knowledge in two areas: psychosocial and professional development. Critical psychosocial elements included LD and STEM identity development, rapport-building with peers and mentors, and serving as a role model for other students. Professional development activities included resume-building, networking, and developing the capacity to pitch oneself to employers. Mentoring was aimed at helping scholars to prepare to participate in undergraduate research, internships, and other cohort activities directly related to their STEM field.

We assessed the efficacy of the program by tracking student retention, graduation, and responses to internal surveys about their experiences. This assessment revealed several key findings about the importance of scholar support and structured cohort experience in increasing retention, graduation rates, and STEM identity. The components identified as important for ND students were developing a sense of self and cohort rapport, creating a community, and developing one’s STEM identity through structured engagement with peers and dedicated faculty mentors.  The AIE-STEM program built upon current support systems at Landmark College (e.g., career connections and advising) and brought these elements together to help ensure the scholars had both financial and educational supports to best position them for success.  

At the conclusion of the grant, we found that students were eager to participate in internships, research, and other professional experiences, but needed assistance getting started on the various processes. Furthermore, they wanted guidance in the soft skills necessary to fully participate. The faculty mentors and career counselors began to provide these supports. Students began to identify themselves practitioners in STEM. Neurodiverse students benefit from mentors and consistent supports that helped to create a sense of community where students could feel a sense of belonging. Honoring and supporting differences is a key component in the success of this community. Scholars thrived in being treated as individuals with differing needs being supported, while still belonging to the community.
